coredata.dc:description: Detailed understanding of the poisoning mechanism in Diesel oxidation catalysts (DOCs) is the key to prevent long term catalyst deterioration in vehicles. The present work studies artificial phosphorus (P) poisoning methods applied to a commercial DOC. Cores of the DOC monolith were exposed to increasing amounts of P precursor by impregnation and by spraying. While impregnation leads to a homogeneous poison distribution in the catalytic layers, elemental analysis revealed that the spraying results in radial and axial P gradients that mimic the distribution of this poison previously observed in vehicle aged DOCs. The activity tests under simulated Diesel exhaust evidenced that P deposition by spraying was more detrimental than by impregnation and caused a more severe decrease in NO oxidation performance. Sequential treatments comprising exposure to P, thermal treatment and exposure to sulphur (S) interleaved by activity tests were performed to gain deeper insight into the catalyst deactivation mechanism.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Artificial P poisoning methods used: a) steps followed for impregnation, b) setup used for spraying and c) schematics of segmentation of sprayed cores for sample characterisation.

a) CO, b) HC (corresponding to the sum of C3H6 and C3H8) and c) NO conversion of samples poisoned with P by impregnation. d) CO, e) HC (corresponding to the sum of C3H6 and C3H8) and f) NO conversion of samples poisoned with P by spraying. The data corresponds to the activity measured during the third heating ramp under 10 vol% O2, 7 vol% H2O, 1000 ppm NO, 500 ppm CO, 150 ppmC1 C3H6/C3H8 (2:1) in N2, at GHSV = 65,000 h−1. Results for the degreened sample (Deg) and NO/NO2 equilibrium (∙∙∙) are also included.
Characterisation of the five consecutive segments of the DOC cores poisoned by spraying: a) P concentration (measured by ICP-OES) and b) SABET (derived from N2 physisorption).

Pore size distributions derived from N2 physisorption isotherms (BJH method). a) Degreened DOC and a model catalyst consisting of the top layer only. The five consecutive segments of the DOC cores poisoned by spraying are given in b) S-0.5P, c) S-1.5P and d) S-2.5P.

SEM images and the corresponding EDS element maps of channel corners in the consecutive segments of S-2.5P. The maps for segments 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 correspond to 0.1, 1.1, 2.1, 3.1, and 4.9 cm from the inlet, respectively.

Quantification of the P content in six areas of the washcoat layer of S-2.5P (segment 1). a) SEM image of a monolith channel corner showing the six areas (labelled A to F) used for EDS elemental quantification. b) P concentration corresponding to each of the six areas.

a) CO, b) HC (corresponding to the sum of C3H6 and C3H8) and c) NO conversion of the sample sequentially exposed to degreening (DegS-PTS), P (S-P), thermal (S-PT) and S (S-PTS) treatments. The data corresponds to the activity during the third heating ramp under 10 vol% O2, 7 vol% H2O, 1000 ppm NO, 500 ppm CO, 150 ppm_C1 C3H6/C3H8 (2:1) in N2, at GHSV of 65,000 h−1. Results of Deg and NO/NO2 equilibrium (∙∙∙) are also included.

Characterisation results for of S-PTS. a) S and P content of the five consecutive segments from inlet to outlet. b) SEM-EDS maps of S and P in a channel corner of the inlet (segment 1) together with the S and P quantification across six areas from the top surface of the washcoat (area A) to the deepest region (area F) as described in Fig. 6.
HAADF-TEM images of the five consecutive segments for S-0.5P (top) and S-PTS (bottom).
PGM particle size distribution in each of the five consecutive segments for S-0.5P (top) and S-PTS (bottom) derived from HAADF-TEM images.

Summary of activity data (T20_CO, T20_HC and Max_NO) and P content (theoretical and measured by ICP-OES) for the cores poisoned by impregnation and spraying. For comparison purposes activity data of Deg is also included.

Characterisation and catalytic activity results for Deg, S-0.5P and S-PTS. The activity for each core is given as T20_CO, T20_HC and Max _NO. For S-PTS the activity after each treatment (i.e. DegS-PTS, S-P, S-PT and S-PTS) is given. After testing, the cores were divided into five segments for analysis of poison content (measured by ICP-OES), average noble metal particle size (derived from TEM images) and surface area (derived from N2 physisorption).

head.ce:title: Understanding the impact of poison distribution on the performance of Diesel oxidation catalysts

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Detailed understanding of the poisoning mechanism in Diesel oxidation catalysts (DOCs) is the key to prevent long term catalyst deterioration in vehicles. The present work studies artificial phosphorus (P) poisoning methods applied to a commercial DOC. Cores of the DOC monolith were exposed to increasing amounts of P precursor by impregnation and by spraying. While impregnation leads to a homogeneous poison distribution in the catalytic layers, elemental analysis revealed that the spraying results in radial and axial P gradients that mimic the distribution of this poison previously observed in vehicle aged DOCs. The activity tests under simulated Diesel exhaust evidenced that P deposition by spraying was more detrimental than by impregnation and caused a more severe decrease in NO oxidation performance. Sequential treatments comprising exposure to P, thermal treatment and exposure to sulphur (S) interleaved by activity tests were performed to gain deeper insight into the catalyst deactivation mechanism.

ce:section.ce:para: Vehicle pollutant emissions – consisting of carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NOx), hydrocarbons (HC) and particulate matter (PM) – must be mitigated by the use of after-treatment systems (ATS). In case of Diesel engines the Diesel oxidation catalyst (DOC) plays an important role in the ATS. The DOC not only burns CO and HC to CO2 and H2O but it also oxidises NO to NO2. The resulting NO2 is then used to oxidise soot in the Diesel particulate filter (DPF) and it is also required for the efficient abatement of NOx in the selective catalytic reduction process (SCR) [1]. SCR is the technology of choice for reducing NOx in the oxygen-rich exhaust gas of lean-burn Diesel engines, typically with ammonia as reductant, generated by the decomposition of urea dosed appropriately into the exhaust aftertreatment system.

Noble metals – also called platinum group metals (PGM) – are widely used in commercial DOCs due to their outstanding catalytic properties. Bimetallic Pt-Pd nanoparticles supported on Al2O3 are typically the active phase, which is washcoated on ceramic monolith substrates [1]. While Pt and Pd are both known to be active for CO and HC oxidation, NO oxidation is reported to occur exclusively on metallic Pt [2–5]. Although more fuel efficient than gasoline engines, the lean-burn Diesel technology exhibits the difficulty of mitigating NOx emissions in its oxygen abundant exhaust. The tightening of NOx emission regulations for Diesel vehicles in recent years [6] has led to changes in DOC composition. For example, increased Pt content is used to improve the NO oxidation functionality. In addition, to mitigate HC and NOx emissions during the engine cold start, current DOCs often include adsorptive components such as zeolites to trap the pollutants until the exhaust reaches sufficiently high temperatures for their catalytic oxidation [7–9]. Considering the multifunctional nature of modern DOCs, optimal overall performance can be achieved by depositing multiple washcoats on the monolith resulting in layers with different functionality [10,11]. Zoning of catalyst formulation along the monolith has also been explored to take advantage of CO and HC oxidation exotherms or to minimise reaction inhibition effects [12–15].

To ensure the efficient mitigation of pollutants it is essential to understand and predict the DOC deterioration during vehicle lifetime. The catalyst performance is often hampered by thermal effects causing sintering as well as by accumulation of chemical poisons during driving. The most common poisons are phosphorus (P) and sulphur (S), which come from fuel impurities and engine lubricants [1,16]. P is known to react with the Al2O3 support forming phosphate species leading to pore blockage and surface area decrease. The direct blockage of noble metal active sites has also been previously proposed [17]. The SO2 present in the Diesel exhaust results in the sulphation of the PGM surface as well as the support; a surface area decrease upon Al2O3 sulphation and the increase in material acidity have also been widely reported [18–20]. Other elements such as Ca, Zn, Fe and Si are often present, albeit in lower amounts [1,16,21,22], and carbon deposits are also known to accumulate with mileage.

Thermal aging and poisoning effects result in overlapping phenomena [17,21,23–27]; for example high temperatures and S exposure are reported to promote noble metal particle growth [24,27–32], while the presence of P prevents such sintering [17,21]. In addition, these effects are known to influence the DOC monoliths in an inhomogeneous manner (i.e. chemical poisoning is more severe in the inlet region of the monoliths while the outlets suffer more from thermal events) [1]. The complexity of the deactivation effects together with the increasingly sophisticated DOC formulations renders the explanation of aging phenomena in vehicles an increasingly challenging task.

Our previous studies have provided a detailed characterisation of a modern DOC aged in a Diesel delivery truck [33]. While thermal sintering was moderate, significant chemical poisoning was observed. Among the compounds accumulated during driving, P was found to be the dominant poison and exhibited a preferential accumulation in the inlet and the top region of the washcoat in agreement with previous reports [22,24,26,34]. Interestingly, S showed a reversed distribution suggesting that the presence of P prevents S accumulation. A strong evidence on the P influence on S distribution was given recently by Honkanen et al. [35] by comparing single and simultaneously poisoned DOCs. In the absence of P, S distributed evenly throughout the catalyst support as aluminium sulphate; in the presence of P however, S adsorption on Al2O3 was prevented. The aluminium phosphate formed upon P exposure was considered to act as a non-sulphating support hindering the migration of sulphur oxides from the Pt to the Al2O3.

Laboratory-based artificial P poisoning studies have brought new insights into the fundamentals of catalyst deactivation [17,36,37]. Wang et al. [37] for example performed vapour phase poisoning over a model DOC using H3PO4 as the precursor and found that the temperature of poisoning affects the overall P content as well as its dispersion in the coating. P2O5, PO3 - and PO4 3- were identified by XPS after poisoning, with the latter compound showing a stronger deactivating effect for the oxidation reactions of the three pollutants.

P poisoning studies by impregnation of H3PO4 solutions were also performed in our lab aiming to match the poison content typically found in vehicle-aged DOC [33]. In such concentrations only the NO conversion was significantly compromised. The subsequent characterisation suggested that the inhibition of noble metal reduction by P compounds could be a deactivating parameter affecting the NO oxidation performance.

In this work we evaluate the impact of two P poisoning approaches applied to a bilayer DOC monolith while drawing comparison to the poison content and distribution reported for vehicle-aged monoliths. The DOC studied comprises two catalytic coatings, of which the top layer is rich in Pt (supported on Al2O3) and holds the NO to NO2 oxidation functionality while the bottom layer contains more Pd as well as zeolite for trapping the HCs. Both layers are believed to contribute to CO and HC oxidation. In parallel to our previous studies – where an equivalent catalyst formulation was modified with P by impregnation – an alternative method is now presented to add P by spraying that leads to inhomogeneous poison distribution in the catalyst. The poison deposition obtained by spraying was evaluated with ICP, SEM-EDS and N2 physisorption after cutting the monolith core into five segments. Coupled with the catalytic activity data, the results help to rationalise the impact of poison distribution on the CO, HC and NO oxidation reactions. To gain a wider picture of the DOC aging process, sequential P, thermal and S treatments are also discussed. These experiments were designed to obtain poison contents and physicochemical properties (e.g. surface area and particle size) relevant to those found in real aged catalysts. We consider that this approach contributes to rationalize the different deactivating phenomena coexisting during real aging of a DOC. Besides, such understanding could lead to future recommendations for catalyst formulations with enhanced poison resistance.

Catalyst: The DOC monolith consisted of 400 cpsi cordierite honeycomb coated with two layers, both comprising Pt and Pd particles as the active sites supported on Al2O3. The total precious metal content was 20 g.ft−3 and Pt:Pd ratio was ca. 5:2. Due to its higher Pt loading, the NO to NO2 oxidation is believed to occur exclusively in the top layer. The bottom layer also contained zeolite to store hydrocarbons below the light-off temperature. An additional model catalyst consisting of the same cordierite honeycomb but coated with the top layer only was also acquired.

P poisoning by impregnation ( Fig. 1 a): Four cores (i.e. monolith segments 1.2 × 1.7 × 5 cm) were cut from the centre of the DOC monolith using a coping saw. The cores were degreened in a horizontal reactor (described hereafter) by exposure to a continuous flow of simulated Diesel exhaust gas (10 vol% O2, 7 vol% H2O, 1000 ppm NO, 500 ppm CO, 150 ppmC1 C3H6/C3H8 (2:1), balance N2) at 525 °C for 4 h and at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 65,000 h−1. One of the degreened cores was left untreated to be used as a reference (denoted as Deg). The remaining cores were impregnated by immersing them into solutions of H3PO4 followed by an overnight drying at 120 °C. The solution concentration was adjusted aiming for a final P content of 0.5, 1.5 and 2.5 wt% in the cores. These samples are denoted as I-0.5P, I-1.5P and I-2.5P, respectively.

P poisoning by spraying (Fig. 1 b): Three additional cores (length = 5 cm and Ø = 1.7 cm) were taken from the centre of the monolith. After degreening, they were wrapped with a ceramic fibre mat and inserted in a vertical quartz reactor (id = 2.0 cm, od = 2.6 cm) fitted with a thermocouple for temperature monitoring. The head of the reactor featured a concentric borosilicate nozzle (Tyfoon ICP nebuliser, EPOND GmbH) connected to 1) a peristaltic pump dosing 4 cm3/h of an aqueous solution of NH4H2PO4 and 2) a nitrogen gas supply (40 dm3/h) to nebulise the dosed solution into a spray. A continuous gas feed of 10 vol% O2 in N2 along the vertical reactor acted as the carrier of the precursor through the catalyst core. The total gas flow was adjusted to a GHSV of 65,000 h−1 and the spray poisoning was performed at 300 °C for 6 h. The carrier gas was also preheated to 300 °C to ensure isothermal conditions in the vertical reactor. We assume that at 300 °C the spray generated in the head of the reactor evaporates leading to the decomposition of the precursor into H3PO4. Using this method the three degreened cores were loaded with increasing P contents aiming for ca. 0.5, 1.5 and 2.5 wt%, which was achieved by adjusting the precursor concentration of the dosed solution. The resulting samples are denoted as S-0.5P, S-1.5P and S-2.5P.

Sequential aging treatments: One additional core (length = 5 cm and Ø = 1.7 cm) was subjected to sequential P, thermal and S treatments. After degreening the sample was sprayed aiming for 0.5 wt% P using the same conditions as described above. This was followed by a thermal treatment under a continuous flow of model Diesel exhaust at 600 °C for 20 h and at GHSV = 65,000 h−1. In a final step, 100 ppm of SO2 were added to the model exhaust gas feed at 250 °C for 16 h. These conditions were selected in order to match the poison content observed in a vehicle aged DOC (288,000 km in Diesel delivery truck [33]). After the final SO2 treatment, the catalyst was exposed to 500 °C (model diesel exhaust at GHSV = 65,000 h−1) for 30 min to remove reversibly adsorbed S species prior to activity testing. DOC activity was evaluated after each treatment and the data after degreening, P, thermal and S treatment are referred to as DegS-PTS, S-P, S-PT and S-PTS, respectively.

The samples were wrapped with ceramic fibre and placed in a horizontal quartz tube reactor (id = 2.5 cm and od = 3.0 cm) operating at ambient pressure. The outlet gas concentration was analysed using a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (Nicolet Antaris IGS) equipped with a 2 m gas cell heated to 180 °C. The temperature in the reactor was recorded with a thermocouple placed in the inlet of the sample. All catalytic tests comprised three consecutive heating-cooling cycles under simulated diesel exhaust (10 vol% O2, 7 vol% H2O, 1000 ppm NO, 500 ppm CO, 150 ppmC1 C3H6/C3H8 (2:1), balance N2) at GHSV = 65,000 h−1. In the first cycle, the binders present in the ceramic fibre mat were burned off when heating the sample to 500 °C at 15 °C/min. After dwelling for 10 min at 500 °C, the temperature was decreased to 100 °C at the same rate. The pre-treatment was followed by two consecutive activity cycles, each performed by heating from 100 °C to 500 °C and then cooling to 100 °C at 5 °C/min. The two activity cycles showed reproducible activity profiles within a level of + /− 2°C for a given conversion; all the results presented in this work correspond to the data collected during the heating ramp of the second activity cycle.

Due to the frequency of spectral acquisition, the low HC concentration and the mixed HC composition (mixture of C3H6 and C3H8) in the gas feed, the conversion exhibited a noisy profile (Fig. S1). Hence, for presentation of HC conversion results, data was smoothed using 20-point averaging method.

Note that in the case of spraying, the same inlet-outlet orientation of the monolith core was used during both poisoning and testing (i.e. the core inlet during poisoning was also the core inlet during testing). The same orientation was used in all steps of the sequential treatments in S-PTS.

The P modified samples were characterised after catalytic testing by means of a range of techniques. To better evaluate the poison gradients resulting after spraying, S-0.5P, S-1.5P and S-2.5P were divided into five consecutive segments from inlet to outlet as shown in Fig. 1 c. The same approach was applied for S-PTS.

The elemental composition of the samples was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) using a Varian Vista AX spectrometer. The samples were dissolved using hydrofluoric acid. All calibration solutions were prepared using 99.999% pure chemicals. The average of three atomic emission lines was used to determine the concentration of the elements of interest.

Nitrogen physisorption measurements were performed at − 196 °C in a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 instrument. Around 150 mg of sample was outgassed at 350 °C overnight under high vacuum prior to the sorption measurements. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation was applied within the p/p° range of ∼0.05–0.30 used to calculate the specific surface area. The pore size distribution was determined by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) analysis of the isotherm desorption branch.

For the scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive spectroscopy (SEM-EDS) analysis, rectangular pieces (10 mm × 10 mm x 30 mm) were cut out from the cores. The cut sections were then embedded at room temperature in EpoFix resin using a resin-to-hardener ratio of 25/3. The samples were subsequently polished and coated with a 10 nm layer of Au using an ion sputter (Leica EM ACE200). The maps were acquired in a ZEISS Ultra-55 Scanning Electron Microscope using an EDAX APOLLO XV Silicon Drift Detector to provide EDS functionality at an accelerating voltage of 12 kV and a working distance of 9.0 mm.

For transmission electron microscopy (TEM), the catalyst washcoat was scraped out from the monoliths and finely ground in an agate mortar. The powder was then suspended in ethanol and a drop of the suspension was deposited on a copper grid coated with a holey carbon film. High-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) images were recorded on a FEI Technai F30 FEG scanning transmission electron microscope equipped with super twin lens and Schottky type emitter at an accelerating voltage of 300 kV. From the electron micrographs of each sample, the particle size of at least 240 noble metal particles were evaluated using ImageJ software [38]. The particles observed had a close to circular shape, the diameter of these circles was taken as the particle size. Using OriginLab software, the particle diameters were then grouped into evenly spaced bins of 1.5 nm wide. This was defined using the Rice estimator (nw = 2n1/3) and following the work-flow proposed by Alxneit [39].

The ICP analysis ( Table 1) revealed that the impregnation method led to P contents of 0.42, 1.42 and 2.40 wt% for I-0.5P, I-1.5P and I-2.5P respectively. In case of the samples prepared by spraying, P contents of 0.46, 1.09 and 2.0 wt% were obtained for S-0.5P, S-1.5P and S-2.5P, respectively. This indicates that for higher P loadings part of the precursor did not interact with the catalyst during spraying and passed through the monolith core without depositing.

To illustrate the impact of the P deposition method on the catalytic activity, Fig. 2 compares the CO, HC and NO conversions of the poisoned samples measured during heating under simulated diesel exhaust conditions. As a reference, the curves for the degreened catalyst (Deg) are also included. The temperatures at 20% conversion for CO (T20_CO) and HC (T20_HC) as well as the maximum NO conversion (Max_NO) are reported in Table 1.

To describe the DOC conversion profiles we commence discussing the degreened sample (Deg). The first light-off during the heating ramp relates to the CO to CO2 conversion [1] (T20_CODeg = 154 °C; Fig. 2a), which showed a sharp rise reaching complete CO oxidation at around 180 °C. This was followed by HC oxidation (T20_HCDeg = 171 °C; Fig. 2b) where the activity exhibits an initial rapid increase of conversion up to 200 °C corresponding to C3H6 oxidation and a more gradual increase above 200 °C due to C3H8 oxidation. Lastly the NO to NO2 oxidation takes place (Fig. 2c), whose conversion commences > 170 °C when most of the C3H6 is converted.

If we now focus our discussion on the P modified samples prepared by impregnation, the CO conversion plots exhibit profiles similar to that of Deg (Fig. 2a) and the T20_CO values show no signs of significant deactivation upon P addition (i.e. ΔT20_CO was < 6 °C among the samples). Nonetheless, the light-off profile of the sample impregnated with higher P content (I-2.5P) presents an additional feature in the high conversion region (Fig. S2a). After a sharp increase in CO conversion up to 97% at 180 °C, the reaction in I-2.5P slows down resulting in a second inflection in the conversion. This retards the complete CO oxidation to 325 °C. Such stepwise profile has been previously reported when CO is co-fed with HC and NO over Pt/Al2O3. While partial oxidation of HC could contribute to the decreased conversion, previous reports attribute such stepwise profile to a reaction inhibition by the accumulation of HC oxidation intermediates on the catalyst surface [40,41]. Regarding the HC conversion (Fig. 2b), little differences were found in the light-off temperatures among the impregnated samples (ΔT20 _HC < 4 °C). The high temperature region (200–500 °C) however exhibits a decreasing conversion with increasing P content indicating that presence of the poison is detrimental to C3H8 oxidation. The reaction inhibition observed for CO in I-2.5P is also expected to equally affect the HC conversion profiles. Fig. S3 represents conversion plots in which the C3H6 and C3H8 profiles are shown separately; unfortunately, no clear conclusion can be extracted in the high temperature region because the HC conversion data are noisy (see original plots in Fig. S1). The NO conversion was significantly compromised by the P addition by impregnation (Fig. 2c). The Max_NO decreased from 63% in Deg to 59% in I-0.5P and I-1.5P while a further decrease to 48% was observed for I-2.5P. Our activity data suggests a greater influence of P on NO oxidation than on CO and HC oxidation reactions; similar results were reported in our earlier work [33]. Considering that NO oxidation occurs exclusively on metallic Pt, IR spectra of adsorbed CO lead us to propose that P-induced Pt oxidation could be a deactivating parameter affecting particularly the NO oxidation performance.

Moving the discussion to the samples prepared by spraying, the CO light-off showed negligible variations (ΔT20_CO < 6 °C; Fig. 2d). The sprayed core with the highest P content (S-2.5P) also exhibited a decrease in CO conversion rate after 180 °C (Fig. S2b). Compared with its impregnated counterpart (I-2.5 P), this feature was more pronounced in the high CO conversion region for S-2.5 P where full CO oxidation was achieved above 400 °C. The HC conversion profiles are equivalent for Deg, S-0.5P and S-1.5P, indicating P addition by spraying had little impact up to 1.1 wt% P. On the other hand, a less sharp light-off and lower conversion levels between 200 and 500 °C evidenced performance deterioration of S-2.5P. Interestingly, compared to the impregnated samples the spraying method was particularly detrimental for NO oxidation. In spite of the lower P deposition obtained by spraying, the NO_Max values showed a significant drop to 56%, 47% and 32% for S-0.5P, S-1.5P and S-2.5P, respectively.

In our previous publication [33], we reported a detailed characterisation of a real aged DOC, in which the P content appeared to decrease from the inlet towards the outlet of the monolith. A gradient within the washcoat thickness was also observed with preferential P accumulation on the top surface of the catalytic coating (more in contact with the gas phase). Similar P distribution has been reported elsewhere for vehicle-aged catalysts [26,42]. We have already reported that unlike in real aged DOC, the modification of the catalyst with P by impregnation resulted in a homogeneous P distribution along the monolith length and within the washcoat thickness (Fig. S4a).

This section evaluates the distribution of P obtained by spraying. To this end, after the activity test the three sprayed cores (S-0.5P, S-1.5P and S-2.5P) were divided into five segments from inlet to outlet for individual analysis (Fig. 1 c). ICP-OES ( Fig. 3a, Table S1) showed that S-2.5P contained the highest P content across the sprayed segments followed by S-1.5P and S-0.5P. For all three samples, the P concentration was highest in the inlet and rapidly decreased towards the outlet exhibiting similar concentration profiles to those of vehicle-aged monoliths. Note that in our previous reports on a vehicle-aged DOC [33], a more gradual P decline was observed along the monolith (Fig. S4b).

The P distribution along the cores had a direct impact on the specific surface areas obtained by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method (SABET). As shown in Fig. 3 b and Table S1 , SABET values were lower in the inlet (segment 1) of the three sprayed cores where P concentration was higher. The values gradually increased towards the outlet. In line, S-2.5P exhibited a lower SABET than S-1.5P and S-0.5P due to its higher P content. This effect was more pronounced in the inlet as this region shows greater differences in poison contents among the samples. The decreased SABET with the presence of P is typically attributed to pore blockage as a result of AlPO4 formation upon reaction of the poison with the support [17,22,43].

Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) analysis of the N2 desorption branches ( Fig. 4 ) revealed a bimodal size distribution in the mesopore range (20–500 Å) with smaller pores with an average diameter of ca. 130 Å and larger pores with an average diameter of ca. 330 Å. Considering the bilayer structure of this DOC, the data of the Deg was compared to that of a model catalyst comprising the top catalytic layer only (Fig. 4 a). The results enable us to assign the smaller pores to the top layer while the larger pores seem to be associated to the bottom layer.

Fig. 4b, c and d show the pore size distributions for the segments in S-0.5P, S-1.5P and S-2.5P, respectively. The porosity was clearly affected by the spraying treatment: consistent with the SABET trends, the intensity of the peaks in the pore size distribution plots exhibited an overall decrease with increasing P content. In S-0.5P for example (Fig. 4b), a lower intensity was observed in the pore size distribution of segment 1 where most of the P accumulated. This evidences pore blockage in the inlet as a result of strong P poisoning. The peak intensity increases towards the outlet due to the decreasing P content. Similar trends were also observed in S-1.5P (Fig. 4c) and S-2.5 P (Fig. 4d). As expected, a more severe pore blockage (i.e. lower intensity in pore distribution plot) was observed in the inlet S-2.5P, which contained the highest fraction of poisons.

Interestingly, the relative intensities for the two types of pores suggest a more pronounced drop in the fraction of the small pores in response to the poisoning. This was mainly observed in the inlet region, where a higher P concentration was found (Fig. 3a).

Guided by the assignment drawn from the one layer model catalyst, the observed trends suggest that pore blockage upon poisoning was more severe in the top layer. This effect can be partly explained by the preferential P accumulation in the upper part of the coating during the spraying process (discussed in the SEM-EDS section hereafter). Additionally, the formulation of the coated layers may also play a role: with the presence of the zeolite in the bottom layer such coating contains less Al2O3 for AlPO4 formation than in the top layer.

Complementary to the ICP-OES analysis used for P quantification along the sprayed cores, SEM-EDS elemental maps of S-2.5P were acquired to gain a qualitative picture of the P distribution in the washcoat depth. The SEM images with the corresponding EDS maps in Fig. 5 depict cross sections of channel corners (perpendicular to the monolith channels) in the five consecutive segments. More specifically, the images correspond to positions at 0.1, 1.1, 2.1, 3.1 and 4.9 cm from the inlet of the core.

The distribution of Mg, Al and Si in the images allows to identify the cordierite substrate as well as the two catalytic layers. Hence, the map of Mg, element present exclusively in the cordierite (Mg2Al4Si5O18), illustrates the boundaries of the substrate channel corner. The bottom catalytic layer, adjacent to the substrate, can be recognised by the presence of Si (i.e. main element of the zeolite component of the bottom layer). The top layer can be recognised by its stronger signal in the Al map, which is consistent with its high Al2O3 content.

It is obvious from Fig. 5 that P strongly penetrated into the washcoat in segment 1. The penetration depth of P decreased downstream towards segment 5 in line with the lower P content measured by ICP-OES (Fig. 3 a). As expected, P accumulated preferentially in the top region of the washcoat.

The P gradient within the washcoat thickness was evaluated by quantification of EDS spectra collected in areas at different washcoat depths ( Fig. 6). The resulting data for segment 1 in S-2.5P illustrates a gradual decrease in P concentration towards deeper regions of the washcoat.

In summary, unlike impregnation, poisoning by spraying lead to P distributions along the length and the depth of the washcoat that are closer to those observed in real aged DOC, i.e. the P accumulation takes place preferentially in the inlet and in the top region of the washcoat. This distribution had a significant impact on the catalytic performance: spraying caused a more severe deactivation, especially for the NO oxidation performance.

Understanding the impact of poison distribution is of particular interest if we consider that modern catalyst technologies often comprise zoned formulations. This means that the catalyst formulation can change in the depth of the washcoat and along the length of the monolith. For the bilayer DOC used in this study for example, the poison distribution upon spraying let us propose that the top layer suffered more severely from the effects of P poisoning and its NO oxidation functionality will be particularly compromised.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Sequential P, T and S treatments
ce:section.ce:para: In addition to P poisoning, PGM sintering due to exposure to exotherms and S compounds in the diesel exhaust gas (leading to the sulphation of the catalyst surface [44]) are known to compromise the DOC performance during driving. To study these effects, a degreened core was exposed to sequential P, thermal and S treatments. The catalytic activity was tested after each treatment to follow the DOC deterioration. After degreening (DegS-PTS), P was deposited by spraying aiming at 0.5 wt% P (step denoted as S-P). The following thermal treatment comprised exposure under simulated Diesel exhaust feed (denoted as S-PT) at 600 °C for 20 h. For the last treatment, 100 ppm of SO2 were added to the simulated exhaust feed at 250 °C for 16 h (denoted as S-PTS). To avoid desorption of S compounds during the activity testing, this final step was followed by a dwell at 500 °C for 30 min. This ensured removal of weakly bound SO2 and sulphite species, which are known to desorb below ca. 350 °C [45].

The conditions above were selected to match the poison content observed in a vehicle-aged DOC (288,000 km in delivery truck) [33]. Besides, the described sequence was specifically designed to simulate the poison distribution and particle sizes expected during aging. Hence, the P treatment was performed in the first place because the presence of such poison is expected to determine both PGM particle morphology and S distribution in subsequent treatments [33,35]. The P spraying was followed by thermal treatment to induce PGM sintering in the presence of P. The S exposure was performed after the thermal treatment because an opposite order may result in the removal of stable sulphates (i.e. surface and bulk Al sulphates) which are known to decompose above ca. 550 °C [45].

The T20_CO, T20_HC and Max_NO values after each treatment in the sequentially treated sample (DegS-TPS, S-P, S-PT and S-PTS) are given in Table 2 together with characterisation results. For comparison purposes Table 2 also includes results for Deg and S-0.5P discussed in the previous section. The conversions after each treatment in S-PTS are shown in Fig. 7. All CO conversion profiles (Fig. 7 a) exhibit a sharp rise after 130 °C reaching full conversion by 170 °C. The T20_CO after each treatment was comparable to that of Deg (T20Deg_CO = 154) although S-P showed a slightly lower value of 145 °C. In any case, it is clear that the treatments did not significantly deteriorate the CO oxidation performance.

The T20_HC values (171, 163, 173 and 167 °C for DegS-PTS, S-P, S-PT and S-PTS, respectively) show that the C3H6 light-off temperature was not compromised by the sequential aging treatments. The slight decrease in conversion > 200 °C suggests that C3H8 oxidation was affected after thermal treatment and SO2 exposure. Note again that conclusions on the C3H8 conversion cannot be readily drawn due to the noisy conversion data. Regarding NO to NO2 oxidation, all treatments seemed to gradually deteriorate the catalyst as Max_NO values were observed to decrease from 64% in DegS-PTS, to 59%, 55% and 48% in S-P, S-PT and S-PTS, respectively. After the sequence of treatments and the activity testing, the S-PTS core was also divided into five segments from inlet to outlet; the characterisation results are shown in Fig. 8 and Table 2.

The total P and S contents, measured by ICP-OES, in the S-PTS core were 0.40 and 0.12 wt%, respectively. These values are comparable to the ones reported for a vehicle-aged DOC with equivalent formulation (i.e. 0.48 and 0.12 wt% of P and S were found after 288,000 km in a delivery truck [33]). To gain understanding on poison distribution, Fig. 8 a shows the P and S content in the different segments along the core. As expected from the spraying procedure, the P concentration was highest in the inlet (1.2 wt% in segment 1) and decreased rapidly towards the outlet (0.08 wt% in segment 5). The S content increased in the opposite direction from inlet (0.07 wt% in segment 1) to outlet (0.17 wt% in segment 5). Fig. 8 b shows the SEM-EDS maps for a channel corner in segment 1 and reveals that the spatial distribution of P and S poisons was reversed within the washcoat. Hence, while P was found in the top region of the washcoat, S accumulation took place in the deeper zones. The poison gradient in the washcoat depth was also corroborated by element quantification from the EDS spectra. The opposite distribution of P and S has also been reported in a vehicle-aged DOC [24,33,34]. In agreement with Honkanen et al. [35], this observation suggests that the presence of P prevents S build-up and its accumulation is relegated to downstream segments and to deeper regions in the washcoat. This behaviour may be attributed to the reversible nature of S poisoning (desorption occurs in exotherms during driving) and the irreversible nature of P poisoning (AlPO4).

Finally, Table 2 also lists the average PGM particle size of the five segments of S-0.5P and S-PTS derived from analysis of HAADF-TEM images. Selected images and the particle size distributions can be found in
Figs. 9 and 10. The results allow to compare the values after P spraying alone, and after the sequential steps comprising also thermal treatment and S exposure. The PGM particles exhibited round morphology in all samples (Fig. 9). The average particle size in the segments of S-0.5P varied from 5.6 to 7.1 nm. The larger particle size obtained for the segments of S-PTS (ranging from 6.9 to 11.5 nm) evidences that PGM sintering occurred during the thermal and SO2 treatments. A similar level of sintering was observed in our previous study where 600 °C–20 h conditions were applied to an equivalent DOC [33]. Hence, we attribute the particle growth in S-PTS to the thermal treatment step. Reports suggest that sintering can occur under similar SO2 exposure conditions as those used here and we therefore cannot rule out the possibility that the applied S treatment may have contributed to the particle growth [31,32].

Interestingly, the segment 1 of S-PTS exhibited smaller particles (6.9 nm) than the downstream segments (10.2–11.5 nm). As P is known to prevent PGM particle growth [17,21], the smaller particles in the inlet are attributed to the increased P content in this section.

It must be mentioned that the PGM particle sizes obtained after the sequential treatments were in the range of those observed in the vehicle-aged DOC (7.8–12.1 nm [33]). This underlines the relevance of the selected treatment to better understand the contribution of thermal effects in the real aged catalyst. Note however, that in the vehicle-aged DOC the particle growth along the monolith was reported to be more gradual [33] than for S-PTS. This can be explained by the fact that the P concentration also decreased linearly along the vehicle-aged DOC, while S-PTS exhibited a more rapid decrease.

Artificial P poisoning methods were applied to a commercial DOC monolith comprising a bilayer formulation, in which the top layer - rich in Pt - is responsible for the NO oxidation functionality. Poisoning by impregnation provided a homogeneous P distribution in the washcoat and lead to slight deterioration of the NO oxidation performance. CO and HC light-off values remained unchanged although conversion profiles above 200 °C evidenced deterioration of CO and HC oxidation performance for higher P contents. For equivalent (and even lower) P dosing, the samples prepared by spraying exhibited a more severe deterioration of the NO conversion which was attributed to the inhomogeneous poison distribution obtained upon spraying. The results of ICP-OES, N2 physisorption and SEM-EDS revealed that P accumulated during spraying preferentially in the inlet and in the top region of the washcoat, a poison distribution typically observed in real aged DOCs. For the studied sample it can be proposed that the top layer suffers more severely from P poisoning, thus compromising its NO oxidation functionality.

Sequential P, thermal and S treatments of the DOC were also carried out and were detrimental, especially to NO conversion. The treatments resulted in a final P and S content of 0.40 and 0.12 wt%, respectively while sintering resulted in an increase of the average particle size to 11.5 nm. These values are comparable to those expected in a real aged DOC [33] allowing for realistic evaluation of poisoning and thermal effects in vehicles. In addition, the characterisation of five consecutive segments along the treated core suggests that the P and S distributions were reversed: S accumulation takes place in locations where the P content is low. This observation suggests that S accumulation in the washcoat is prevented by the presence of P.

Inhomogeneous poisoning patterns such as those obtained in our lab scale experiment have been long observed in vehicle aged DOC. Note however, that the used spraying conditions resulted in a sharp decrease of the P content from inlet to outlet while a more linear decrease has been observed for monoliths aged in a vehicle. In future, the spraying conditions used here (e.g. gas flow over the catalyst, core length, spraying temperature, and precursor) could be potentially optimised to tune the poison distribution and to evaluate the impact of different P gradients. The spraying method could be further used to study poisoning by alkali elements commonly found in vehicle-aged DOCs. Unlike NH4H2PO4, precursors of these metals are thermally stable and the addition to the gas feed by means of a two-fluid nozzle produces a stable spray that allows homogeneous poison dosage.

Finally, we believe that the data presented here bring new insight into the DOC aging process regarding the correlation between poison distribution and DOC activity. This knowledge is of special importance in the case of layered or zoned catalysts that hold different functionalities in radial and axial directions and could potentially be used to design zoned DOC formulations with increased chemical resistance.

Miren Agote-Arán: Investigation, Data curation, Visualization, Writing – original draft, Writing – review & editing. Martin Elsener: Investigation, Data curation, Writing – review & editing. Frank W. Schütze: Resources, Writing – review & editing. Christian M. Schilling: Resources, Writing – review & editing. Manasa Sridhar: Conceptualization, Resources, Project administration. Evangelos Katsaounis: Resources, Project administration. Oliver Kröcher: Conceptualization, Writing – review & editing, Project administration. Davide Ferri: Conceptualization, Funding acquisition, Visualization, Writing – review & editing.
